intro: Monticalia apiculata, commonly known as the white-flowered mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on the branches of host trees. It belongs to the family Viscaraceae and is characterized by its evergreen leaves and small, white or pale yellow flowers. The plant lacks chlorophyll and relies on its host for nutrients, while also providing shelter for various insects and birds. It is native to parts of Southeast Asia, including Malaysia and Indonesia. Due to its parasitic nature and ecological role, it plays a significant part in the biodiversity of its forest ecosystems.
